column1: A custom cron expression can be entered here. Make sure to set "Cronjob Frequency" to "Use custom frequency" if you want to enter a custom cron expression here. To set up multiple cronjobs, separate multiple cron expressions by a semi-colon ; Example: */5 * * * *;0 3 * * *

column1:
REQUIRED: Set the field delimiter (one character only). Example field delimiter: ;
Hint: If you want to use a tab delimited file enter: \t
column2:
REQUIRED: Set the field delimiter (one character only). Example field delimiter: ;
Hint: If you want to use a tab delimited file enter: \t

column1: Set the field enclosure character (one character only, if fields are wrapped in quotes for example). Example: "
column2: Set the field enclosure character (one character only, if fields are wrapped in quotes for example). Example: "

column1:
Set the XPath for the node containing the order updates.

Example XML file:
<items>
<item>
...
</item>
<item>
...
</item>

</items>
The order updates would be located in each "item" node, which are located in the "items" node, so the XPath would be: //items/item

Every "item" node located under the "items" node would be processed then.
column2:
Set the XPath for the node containing the order updates.

Example XML file:
<items>
<item>
...
</item>
<item>
...
</item>

</items>
The order updates would be located in each "item" node, which are located in the "items" node, so the XPath would be: //items/item

Every "item" node located under the "items" node would be processed then.

column1: The settings specified below will be applied to all manual and automatic imports.
column2: The settings specified below will be applied to all manual and automatic imports.

column1: This is what is called the Order Identifier in the import settings and is what's used to identify the orders in the import file. Almost always you will want to use the Order Increment ID (Example: 100000001).
column2: This is what is called the Order Identifier in the import settings and is what's used to identify the orders in the import file. Almost always you will want to use the Order Increment ID (Example: 100000001).

column1: This is what is called the Product Identifier in the import settings and is what's used to identify the product in the import file. Almost always you will want to use the SKU.
column2: This is what is called the Product Identifier in the import settings and is what's used to identify the product in the import file. Almost always you will want to use the SKU.

column1: IMPORTANT: This is not the attribute name. It is the attribute code you assigned to the attribute.
column2: IMPORTANT: This is not the attribute name. It is the attribute code you assigned to the attribute.

column1: Assign a name to identify this source in logs/profiles.
column2: Assign a name to identify this source in logs/profiles.

column1:
You can set up an own class in our (or another) module which gets called when importing. The loadFiles() function would be called in your class. If your class was called \Xtento\TrackingImport\Model\Source\Myclass then the identifier to enter here would be \Xtento\TrackingImport\Model\Source\Myclass

The loadFiles() function needs to return an array like this: array(array('source_id' => $this->getSource()->getId(), 'filename' => $filename, 'data' => $fileContents))
column2:
You can set up an own class in our (or another) module which gets called when importing. The loadFiles() function would be called in your class. If your class was called \Xtento\TrackingImport\Model\Source\Myclass then the identifier to enter here would be \Xtento\TrackingImport\Model\Source\Myclass

The loadFiles() function needs to return an array like this: array(array('source_id' => $this->getSource()->getId(), 'filename' => $filename, 'data' => $fileContents))

column1: Important: Only SFTPv3 servers are supported. Please make sure the server you're trying to connect to is a SFTPv3 server.
column2: Important: Only SFTPv3 servers are supported. Please make sure the server you're trying to connect to is a SFTPv3 server.

column1: FTPS is only available if PHP has been compiled with OpenSSL support. Only some server versions are supported, support is limited by PHP.
column2: FTPS is only available if PHP has been compiled with OpenSSL support. Only some server versions are supported, support is limited by PHP.

column2: Timeout in seconds after which the connection to the server fails

column2: If your server is behind a firewall, or if the extension has problems uploading the imported files, please set this to "Yes".

column1: This is the absolute path to the directory on the server where files will be downloaded from. This directory has to exist on the FTP server.
column2: This is the absolute path to the directory on the server where files will be downloaded from. This directory has to exist on the FTP server.

column1: This needs to be a valid regular expression. The regular expression will be used to detect import files. The import will fail if the pattern is invalid. Example: /csv/i for all files with the csv file extension or for all files in the import directory: //
column2: This needs to be a valid regular expression. The regular expression will be used to detect import files. The import will fail if the pattern is invalid. Example: /csv/i for all files with the csv file extension or for all files in the import directory: //

column1: If you want to move the imported file(s) to another directory after they have been processed, please enter the path here. This is the absolute path to the archive directory on the FTP server. This directory has to exist on the FTP server. Leave empty if you don't want to archive the import files.
column2: If you want to move the imported file(s) to another directory after they have been processed, please enter the path here. This is the absolute path to the archive directory on the FTP server. This directory has to exist on the FTP server. Leave empty if you don't want to archive the import files.

column1: Set this to "Yes" if you want to delete the imported file from the FTP server after it has been processed. You can't delete and archive at the same time, so choose either this option or the archive option above.
column2: Set this to "Yes" if you want to delete the imported file from the FTP server after it has been processed. You can't delete and archive at the same time, so choose either this option or the archive option above.

column1: This is no valid regular expression. It needs to begin and end with slashes: /sample/
column2: This is no valid regular expression. It needs to begin and end with slashes: /sample/

column1:
Instructions: To import data to a HTTP server, please follow the following steps:
1) Go into the app/code/Xtento/TrackingImport/Model/Source/ directory and rename the file "Http.php.sample" to "Http.php"
2) Enter the function name you want to call in the Http.php class in the field below.
3) Open the Http.php file and add a function that matches the function name you entered. This function will be called by this source upon importing then.

Example: If you enter server1 in the function name field below, a method called server1() must exist in the Http.php file. This way multiple HTTP servers can be added to the HTTP class, and can be called from different import source, separated by the function name that is called. The function you add then gets called whenever this source is executed by an import profile.
column2:
Instructions: To import data to a HTTP server, please follow the following steps:
1) Go into the app/code/Xtento/TrackingImport/Model/Source/ directory and rename the file "Http.php.sample" to "Http.php"
2) Enter the function name you want to call in the Http.php class in the field below.
3) Open the Http.php file and add a function that matches the function name you entered. This function will be called by this source upon importing then.

Example: If you enter server1 in the function name field below, a method called server1() must exist in the Http.php file. This way multiple HTTP servers can be added to the HTTP class, and can be called from different import source, separated by the function name that is called. The function you add then gets called whenever this source is executed by an import profile.

column1:

public function yourFunctionName() { ... }
column2:
Please make sure the function you enter exists like this in the app/code/Xtento/TrackingImport/Model/Source/Http.php file:

column1: Instructions: This source is able to download files from a HTTP server. Please supply an URL in the following format: http://www.url.com/file.csv - It can be any url with any valid path/filename that exists on the remote webserver. To provide a username/password in the URL, please use: http://username:password@www.url.com/file.csv
column2: Instructions: This source is able to download files from a HTTP server. Please supply an URL in the following format: http://www.url.com/file.csv - It can be any url with any valid path/filename that exists on the remote webserver. To provide a username/password in the URL, please use: http://username:password@www.url.com/file.csv

column1: Path to the directory where import files will be searched in. Use an absolute path or specify a path relative to the Magento root directory by putting a dot at the beginning. Example to import from the var/import/ directory located in the root directory of Magento: ./var/import/  Example to import from an absolute directory: /var/www/test/ would import from the absolute path /var/www/test (and not located in the Magento installation)
column2: Path to the directory where import files will be searched in. Use an absolute path or specify a path relative to the Magento root directory by putting a dot at the beginning. Example to import from the var/import/ directory located in the root directory of Magento: ./var/import/  Example to import from an absolute directory: /var/www/test/ would import from the absolute path /var/www/test (and not located in the Magento installation)

column1: If you want to move the imported file(s) to another directory after they have been processed, please enter the path here. Use an absolute path or specify a path relative to the Magento root directory by putting a dot at the beginning. Example to move to the var/import/archive/ directory located in the root directory of Magento: ./var/import/archive/  Example to move to an absolute directory: /var/www/test/archive/ would move to the absolute path /var/www/test/archive/ (and not located in the Magento installation) This directory has to exist. Leave empty if you don't want to archive the import files.
column2: If you want to move the imported file(s) to another directory after they have been processed, please enter the path here. Use an absolute path or specify a path relative to the Magento root directory by putting a dot at the beginning. Example to move to the var/import/archive/ directory located in the root directory of Magento: ./var/import/archive/  Example to move to an absolute directory: /var/www/test/archive/ would move to the absolute path /var/www/test/archive/ (and not located in the Magento installation) This directory has to exist. Leave empty if you don't want to archive the import files.

column1: Set this to "Yes" if you want to delete the imported file from the local directory after it has been processed. You can't delete and archive at the same time, so choose either this option or the archive option above.
column2: Set this to "Yes" if you want to delete the imported file from the local directory after it has been processed. You can't delete and archive at the same time, so choose either this option or the archive option above.

column1:
Instructions: To import data from a webservice, please follow the following steps:
1) Go into the app/code/Xtento/TrackingImport/Model/Source/ directory and rename the file "Webservice.php.sample" to "Webservice.php"
2) Enter the function name you want to call in the Webservice.php class in the field below.
3) Open the Webservice.php file and add a function that matches the function name you entered. This function will be called by this source upon importing then.

Example: If you enter server1 in the function name field below, a method called server1() must exist in the Webservice.php file. This way multiple webservices can be added to the Webservice class, and can be called from different import source, separated by the function name that is called. The function you add then gets called whenever this source is executed by an import profile.

Important: The custom function needs to return an array like this: array(array('source_id' => $this->getSource()->getId(), 'filename' => $filename, 'data' => $fileContents))
column2:

3) Open the Webservice.php file and add a function that matches the function name you entered. This function will be called by this source upon importing then.

Example: If you enter server1 in the function name field below, a method called server1() must exist in the Webservice.php file. This way multiple webservices can be added to the Webservice class, and can be called from different import source, separated by the function name that is called. The function you add then gets called whenever this source is executed by an import profile.

Important: The custom function needs to return an array like this: array(array('source_id' => $this->getSource()->getId(), 'filename' => $filename, 'data' => $fileContents))

column1: This will try to capture the payment at the payment gateway, i.e. charge the credit card if you authorized the payment.
column2: This will try to capture the payment at the payment gateway, i.e. charge the credit card if you authorized the payment.

column1: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get invoiced for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be invoiced completely.
column2: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get invoiced for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be invoiced completely.

column1: Import no shipments without tracking numbers
column2: Import no shipments without tracking numbers

column1: If set to "Yes" orders without tracking numbers will not be imported.
column2: If set to "Yes" orders without tracking numbers will not be imported.

column1: Add tracking numbers to existing shipments & import multiple tracking numbers
column2: Add tracking numbers to existing shipments & import multiple tracking numbers

column1: If the import file contains more than one tracking number for one order or if the order has been already shipped, these tracking numbers will get added to the most recent shipment of the order.
column2: If the import file contains more than one tracking number for one order or if the order has been already shipped, these tracking numbers will get added to the most recent shipment of the order.

column1: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get shipped for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be shipped completely.
column2: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get shipped for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be shipped completely.

column1: Create credit memo for imported order
column2: Create credit memo for imported order

column1: Send credit memo email to customer
column2: Send credit memo email to customer

column1: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get refunded for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be refunded completely.
column2: This requires the SKU and quantity fields in the import file to be filled with data. The order will then only get refunded for the imported SKU and quantity. Otherwise the order will simply be refunded completely.

column1: This will cancel the order and all items in the order, if it can be cancelled. This is only possible if it has not been invoiced/shipped yet.
column2: This will cancel the order and all items in the order, if it can be cancelled. This is only possible if it has not been invoiced/shipped yet.

column1: Change order status to the status defined in the "Order Status" column in the import file
column2: Change order status to the status defined in the "Order Status" column in the import file

column1: This will set the order status to whatever status is defined in the Order Status column in the import file.
column2: This will set the order status to whatever status is defined in the Order Status column in the import file.

column1: Change order status after importing partial order
column2: Change order status after importing partial order

column1:
If a partial shipped/invoiced order gets imported, change the order status to a specific status.
                Attention: Do not use the "On Hold" status for partial shipments, as otherwise no further shipments can be created.
column2:
If a partial shipped/invoiced order gets imported, change the order status to a specific status.
                Attention: Do not use the "On Hold" status for partial shipments, as otherwise no further shipments can be created.

column1: Change order status after import (or when order has been completely invoiced/shipped)
column2: Change order status after import (or when order has been completely invoiced/shipped)

column1: You can either import the status from the file you are importing (see processor options), or statically change the order status to the status set here after the order has been completely shipped.
column2: You can either import the status from the file you are importing (see processor options), or statically change the order status to the status set here after the order has been completely shipped.

column1: Send order update email to customer (see help)
column2: Send order update email to customer (see help)

column1: If enabled, the order update email will be sent to the customer. This is the same email that also gets sent if you add a comment to an order from the Orders view, so it makes sense especially if you add an order comment. Note, this only works if order update emails are enabled in System - Configuration.
column2: If enabled, the order update email will be sent to the customer. This is the same email that also gets sent if you add a comment to an order from the Orders view, so it makes sense especially if you add an order comment. Note, this only works if order update emails are enabled in System - Configuration.

column1: This is the field used to identify orders in Magento. Usually the order number, but based on the setting in the Import Settings tab, this may be the invoice number for example too.
column2: This is the field used to identify orders in Magento. Usually the order number, but based on the setting in the Import Settings tab, this may be the invoice number for example too.

column1: This is mapped to the order status set for the order. This must be a valid order status code seen at System > Order Statuses.
column2: This is mapped to the order status set for the order. This must be a valid order status code seen at System > Order Statuses.

column1: Comment that is added into the order status history after the order was updated.
column2: Comment that is added into the order status history after the order was updated.

column1: The tracking number added to the imported/updated shpiment
column2: The tracking number added to the imported/updated shpiment

column1: The carrier code for the tracking number imported. Make sure this is a valid tracker code, out of the box it is usps, ups, dhl or fedex. If you are using our Custom Carrier Trackers extension, its tracker codes are tracker1 through tracker15.
column2: The carrier code for the tracking number imported. Make sure this is a valid tracker code, out of the box it is usps, ups, dhl or fedex. If you are using our Custom Carrier Trackers extension, its tracker codes are tracker1 through tracker15.

column1: Could not connect to FTP server. Please make sure that there is no firewall blocking the outgoing connection to the FTP server and that the timeout is set to a high enough value. If this error keeps occurring, please get in touch with your server hoster / server administrator AND with the server hoster / server administrator of the remote FTP server. A firewall is probably blocking ingoing/outgoing FTP connections.
column2: Could not connect to FTP server. Please make sure that there is no firewall blocking the outgoing connection to the FTP server and that the timeout is set to a high enough value. If this error keeps occurring, please get in touch with your server hoster / server administrator AND with the server hoster / server administrator of the remote FTP server. A firewall is probably blocking ingoing/outgoing FTP connections.
